transcripts.text: We have another caller coming up.  This is Duncan from Texas, and you wanted to ask us... Hey, how's it going?  I have a note here saying you wanted to ask us for the basis of our belief in atheism.  Is that right?

Yeah, I'm just wondering what the rational basis for atheism is, whether you define it as the denial of the existence of God or lack of belief.  If you lack belief in God, what is it then that ultimately exists?  that would tie everything together and be a basis for rationality?  What would be the impersonal ultimate that would exist that would replace God?
Well, this isn't Matt Slick, is it?
No.
Okay.  Sorry, say again.
I said I'm not Matt Slick.  Okay, cool.
Just making sure.  Because if you are, then lying is a sin.  I'll just let you know.
I'm not.
Do you know who Matt Slick is?
Yeah, I've seen him on YouTube many times.

Okay, okay.  Well, I think that's an interesting question.  I don't know if atheism is the rationality or the basis for my rationality.  I think if it was, then I'd have to justify that, but it's not.
Well, what ultimately exists, since you lack belief in God, you must have a belief that something is ultimate or absolute.
Why do I need to have a belief in something ultimate?
Well, then what would be the basis for your belief in any states of affairs, including reason?  What prerequisites would exist?  for your capacity to reason or have epistemology.
I don't know if I need a prerequisite for reason.  I think everyone has it.  I mean, you know, obviously reason...
Your brain isn't the prerequisite for reason?
Well, I mean, I need a brain to reason things, yeah.
And does your brain operate in terms of causality and laws of nature, and do they exist?
From what I can observe...
Can you observe causality?
Can I observe causality?  I can observe events happening and then other events happening.

Right, but I'm just saying the causal principle.  Can you observe that there are causal relations between events?  Because if you can't account for causality... then how are you going to account for reason?  Since you require justification for God, then if matter, energy, causality, and laws of nature replace God as the basis for you to reason, how do you account for causality and laws of nature?  Because you can't appeal to sense perception.
Why do I have to account?  Are you saying account as in I have to prove that causes exist?
Yeah, is causality and laws of nature a prerequisite to reason and epistemology?
You do realize laws of nature were made by our reason.  They describe how things work.
Yeah, do they exist?
They're descriptions of how things work.
Okay, but are there laws of nature and are there causal connections between events?  that would be a prerequisite for your capacity to reason and have epistemology?

There are descriptions for how things work that we came up with our reason and our intellects to describe the world in which we live.  I don't see why we have to have a precept ultimate source of any of this.  Atheism is the answer to a single question.
Yeah, but when you have your atheism, you lack belief in God because God's not rationally justified, right?
I don't have atheism.  I am an atheist, but that's the answer to a single question.
You lack belief in God through the process of reason.  What ultimately exists that provides for your capacity to reason?  Is it laws of nature?
I think that's an equivocation because I'm using reason to come to my conclusions.
Oh, I understand that you're using reason.  I'm just simply saying to you, how do you account for the prerequisites that you are reasoning?
Are you trying to say how do I account that my reasoning is accurate?
I just want to see if you actually have a reliable method.  to be able to reason.  Do the prerequisites for reason exist in order for...
Oh, are there like axioms that I accept?  Maybe.  Is that what you're asking?
Are those axioms adopted by blind faith or do they have a justification?
Yeah, so it depends because I think different people adopt different axioms depending on what kind of atheist you ask.

Well, what about you?  Are your most bottom basic beliefs adopted by blind faith about the nature of reality?  Or do you have a justification for it?  Because you insist that God has to have a rational justification, right?

To hold a belief in God, not necessarily that God exists.  It's two different things in my opinion.  Because I don't know ultimate truth or whatever.  I know how to justify my beliefs in order to accurately accommodate them with reality, at least the reality that I perceive it.
So the prerequisites for reasons such as causality and laws of nature do exist?
The prerequisites, okay, that's a lot.  Can you repeat that a little more slowly so that I can understand?
Do the prerequisites of reason, such as causality and laws of nature, actually exist in order for you to be able to reason and have epistemology?
Well, I mean, we observe them through reason.  So I don't know.
Reason is not sense perception.
Yeah, but we have to reason that they exist through our observations.

Well, you can't appeal to sense perception to justify causality and laws of nature because sense perception entails causality and laws of nature in order to be a meaningful concept.  That would be begging the question.  So you can't appeal to something that presupposes causality and laws of nature in order to justify laws of nature.  So as an atheist, since you lack belief in God, you must believe in something that ultimately exists that makes God unnecessary, such as matter, energy, causality, and laws of nature.  So what's your justification?
Is this Darth Dawkins?
I do use that name, yes.
There you go.
Yes, that's what I thought.
Do you have a justification for that, gentlemen?
I disagree with the premise.
Yeah, the premises are garbage.
You disagree.  that reason has the prerequisites of causality and laws of nature?
I think you don't understand what laws of nature are.
Okay, well, the question I'm asking you, gentlemen, is since reason requires certain prerequisites that nature operate in a certain way, otherwise you wouldn't have the capacity to reason.

No, they don't require that.  We know the reason why we can justify that they do is because we're using reason.  Okay, they don't already, we don't, you know, accept that to be true a priori.  We're having to use our reason to come to those conclusions.  I think you're getting it backwards.  You can't call that a prerequisite because we're using reason to figure that out.
By our reason, we describe how things happen, and we call those the laws of nature.
Yeah.  They're descriptions that we use our reason for.
Right.
If our observations told us something else, that there weren't causes, that things just happened randomly, then we would...
How do you know things aren't happening randomly?
Well, my sense perceptions don't tell me that they are.

No, no, you can't.  You see, you wouldn't be able to.  How would you be able to distinguish between a random chance world where events are spontaneous, producing the same kinds of consistency as necessity?  How would you be able to know the difference?
What would be the difference?
Yeah.
I'm asking – that's what I'm asking you.
No, I'm saying like even if it was random and everything worked exactly the same way it is, then what does random even mean?
Well, if all events were random and spontaneous, would you have the capacity to reason?  No.  So you must presuppose there's laws of nature and causality.  Do you have
– No, I would have to presuppose
that – How did you figure that out?  You used your reason to figure that out.  So you're using reason to do that.
I'm just asking how you account for it.
That's how I account for it.  I use my reason.
Yes, we use our reason.
Yeah.
Right.  So you're saying I reason, therefore I reason?  No.  Is that what you're saying?
When did I say that?  No.
I'm asking you.
What does that even mean?
What I'm asking you is reason has prerequisites.
No, it doesn't.

Can I finish my statement, please?  If you lack belief in God as the ultimate prerequisite for reason, then something else must ultimately exist, such as matter, energy, causality, and laws of nature to provide a foundation for you to have reason forever.  And epistemology.  And I want to see if you can account for the prerequisites of your claim to reason.  Can you justify that there are laws of nature?
First of all, God is not a reason for reasons.
In certain worldviews, God would be...
The existence of a God does not confirm that you know things about reality.  In no way does that make sense.

What I'm simply saying is, in certain models of worldview, such as the Christian worldview, which I hold to, God would be the ultimacy of reality, which is the ultimate prerequisite for everything, including reason.
Are you a reformed epistemologist, or are you... Just a typical, like, what is your...
I'm a Bible-believing Christian, sir.
Your specific worldview, though, because there's like millions and millions of millions and millions of Christians that disagree with what you just said.
I'm a Bible-believing Christian.  I believe that the Bible is literal from Genesis to Revelation.  Now, can I get back to my question?
Well, because Christianity...

Yeah, I understand that.  But see, my question is about how do you account for your capacity to- And I gave you my reason and you have rejected it.  May I finish my question?  In your worldview, something must ultimately exist as a foundation and a prerequisite that provides-.
Okay, so this is the fifth time you've said this.  And again, I reject your premise.
Yes.  What do you mean?
My answer is no.
No.  So there's no absolute in existence that provides a foundation for reason?
No absolute.  I don't know what that means.
How would we know what an absolute is?
Yeah, we don't have the ability to tell.

Well, let me put it this way.  I'm sure you agree that all assertions or propositions require context.  So when you make assertions about reason, what's the ultimate or absolute context of reality that provides the meaning for your capacity?
I don't have one.  Nobody has that ability.
If you don't have one, then how do you know you can reason?

No, it's not that I don't know I can reason.  See, that's, that's where you messed up.  Okay.  I never said I couldn't reason.  My reasoning could be faulty, but that doesn't mean I can't reason.  You see the difference?  I could reason false conclusions.  That is possible, but you can't say I can't.
Dan, can I just tell you something?  This is Darth Dawkins.  He has been trying for months to get on my channel with me in a chat for just this reason.  It never gets better.
I'm not sure what you're even talking about trying to get on your channel.  What are you referring to, sir?
You have been in my chat countless times asking to join.
I'm not sure what you're referring to.  I sent you one message, I think, asking if you wanted to have a dialogue.  Just one message, sir.  How does one message equal countless times?
My reason.
I sent you one direct message, sir.  All right.
Well, regardless.
Anyway, but that's changing the subject.  So the point of what I want to say is since you lack belief in God, if you have no foundation in terms of your worldview.
I do have a foundation.
How is your reason meaningful?

I do have a foundation.  Why are you saying that I don't?  I do.  My sensory perceptions of the world and my reasoning abilities are my foundation.  No, they're not ultimate.  They're not ultimate, and I'm not making the claim that they are.

I don't need ultimate.  an ultimate foundation.  You're going to need, you're going to need a bottom level foundation about what the nature of existence is in order to claim that you can have a position of reason.
No, because first of all, I have to, you're assuming I have to, I'd have to have a foundation to, in order to come to that conclusion anyway.  So it's kind of defeats the purpose.
So do you believe in that foundation that provides you the capacity to reason by faith or by evidence?

No, gosh.  We've gone through this several times, and I've seen you talk about this with other people.  I'm not really interested in having this conversation because I don't think that it's meaningful, and I don't think it's simple either.  No, it's not.  Why?
Because you can't answer the question?
No, actually, I've answered it several times, and other people have answered it as well.
Well, is it by blind faith or by evidence that the foundation is there?  And what is that foundation?
It's by neither.  I've already told you it's my sensory experiences and my reason that I make claims about my perception of reality.
Are not your sensory apparatus, are they not contingent upon prerequisites?

Okay, so we kind of talked about this before, but I'm interested in what you mean by prerequisites. I think that I can still use my reasoning abilities and I would still be able to tell because we can tell things about.  supposedly there are quantum events that happen that don't happen on a cause-effect-cause-effect basis. Does nature, the way it operates, provide the foundation for you to reason about anything as an atheist?  And is the way nature operates, is that causality and laws of nature? Those aren't my foundations.
No.
Okay.  Thank you for calling.  I really do appreciate you calling.
So you don't want to answer the question, huh?
I've answered the question several times and I have other callers that I like to talk to because we're going around in circles.
You haven't answered the question.  You've just talked around it.  You haven't answered it in the least.  We've answered it constantly.
Darth, how many times have I told you what my foundations are?
I didn't hear what your foundation is.

Okay, so you did hear.  Okay, so you lied.  Okay, so there's one.  You did actually hear what I said. Okay, I'm done with this conversation.  Thank you for calling, Darth.  Have a nice day. I'm not there for this.
